title: Does Britain still economically benefit from its former colonies in any way? - Quora
tags: Colonial Contribution to the UK Economy

response.answer_text: Nope. Far more money was spend in their maintenance then any profit for the country as a whole. Few individuals, obviously, profited but that is something else.That doesn’t mean colonies were useless. Some colonies, such as India or American were great source of trade, and this was profitable, although in almost all cases the exploitation of these resources were not done by British, they paid for good, although typically had very good trade deals (as in you MUST trade with us). Colonies were about prestige, and about the idea of Mercantilism society whereby balance of trade was viewed as the best thing. This is a false thinking. What brings wealth isn’t trade balance, but trade itself. Most countries never learned that and hence either collapsed (such as Spain) or struggled, such as Portugal.

Yes, all the British colonies are far wealthier than before their brief spell under British management, with the pre existing, largely subsistence agrarian, economies replaced with at least partially industrialised market economies, ports built along their coast lines, communication and power networks laid, airports built, all to permit them to consume British Goods and Services, for mutual gain. The likes of the USA, Hong Kong, Singapore, Ireland, Australia, UAE, Egypt, … see( List of the largest trading partners of United Kingdom - Wikipedia ) all import millions from the mother country, and many pop over, on British originated, mechanical transport, and spend, see: Office for National Statistics

Yes. This is known as Neo-Imperialism. Companies based in Britain and other European powers own resources and infrastructure in former colonies. This gives them priority access to the profits from these assets at the expense of the locals.
